title: American Apparel to close stores and cut jobs
text:
American Apparel is undertaking US$30m in cost-cutting initiatives 
American Apparel Inc has announced plans to close underperforming stores and streamline its workforce in phase two of its turnaround plan, as the retailer battles headwinds and attempts to cut costs. 
As part of US$30m in cost-cutting initiatives over the next 18 months, the US fashion group said it will reduce its footprint in unprofitable and over-saturated markets, and add stores in more profitable, fast-growing territories. 
The company hasn't yet placed a number of the amount of stores or employees that will be affected, but is hoping the initiative will better align its cost structure with competitive, promotional and foreign exchange headwinds. 
American Apparel says the move, which will take effect immediately, is aimed at stabilising the company financially as it looks to address a number of legacy issues including strengthening its creative marketing, maximising new retail, e-commerce and wholesale opportunities, increasing supply chain agility, and improving expense management processes. 
The company is also party to 20 lawsuits and administrative actions initiated by founder Dov Charney and his associates, which American Apparel says are "meritless" and intends to "vigorously defend" where possible, pursuing remedies against him for his actions. 
"We are committed to turning this company around," said newly appointed CEO Paula Schneider. "Today's announcements are necessary steps to help American Apparel adapt to headwinds in the retail industry, preserve jobs for the overwhelming majority of our 10,000 employees, and return the business to long-term profitability. 
"Our primary focus is on improving the processes and product mix that have led to steep losses over the past five years. Our customers, employees, and local communities around the world believe that American Apparel is an iconic brand that deserves to succeed. My job is to make that a reality." 
Additionally, the company announced the appointments of Christine Olcu as general manager of global retail and Brad Gebhard as president of wholesale to help execute its global retail and wholesale turnaround strategies.
